intro: Macropodanthus sabahensis, commonly known as the Sabah ghostflower, is a rare and endemic plant species found in the Bornean rainforests of Malaysia. It is a member of the Aizoaceae family, characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves and unique adaptations for arid conditions. The plant produces small, star-shaped flowers that are typically pale green or white, which help it blend with its surroundings. It thrives in rocky or gravelly soils and is often found in shaded, humid environments. Due to habitat loss, it is considered threatened and is of great interest to botanists and conservationists.
